The bodhisattvas such as DharmapÄla composed the Cheng Weishi Lun based on these thirty verses. Now, I will briefly indicate the reasons.
Namely, in these thirty verses, the first twenty-four lines explain the characteristics of consciousness-only;
The next one line explains the nature of consciousness-only;
The last five lines explain the stages of practice of consciousness-only.
Within the twenty-four lines, the first one and a half lines briefly discuss the characteristics of consciousness-only;
The next twenty-two and a half lines extensively discuss the characteristics of consciousness-only.
Namely, an external question says:
If there is only consciousness, how do the worldly and the holy teachings speak of the existence of self and dharmas?
Raising a verse in response, the verse says:
There are various characteristics that arise.
They depend on the transformation of consciousness; these three are able to transform.
2. The second is the consciousness of retribution, thinking, and discriminating objects.

The next twenty-two and a half lines extensively discuss the characteristics of consciousness only. This is because the previous verse briefly mentions the three transforming [consciousnesses], and now it extensively clarifies the characteristics of the three transformations.
First, what are the characteristics of the first transforming [consciousness]?
The verse says:
The first is the Älaya consciousness, the consciousness of retribution, and all seeds,
It always corresponds to touch,
Attention, feeling, perception, and volition, and only has the feeling of indifference.
Touch and so forth are also like this.
It constantly transforms like a flowing stream, and is abandoned in the state of arhatship.
Having explained the first transforming [consciousness], what are the characteristics of the second transforming [consciousness]?

It refers to ignorance of self, view of self,
Along with conceit, self-love, and other contacts and so forth.
, Following the arising and bondage,
Arhats, cessation samÄdhi, and supramundane paths do not have them.
Thus the second transforming consciousness has been explained. What are the characteristics of the third transforming consciousness?

, Distinguishing objects, good, afflictions,

Having explained the mental factors associated with the six consciousnesses, how should one understand their present mode of occurrence?
In verse it is said:
The five consciousnesses appear following conditions,
sometimes together, sometimes not together, like waves and ripples in water.
Except when born in the heaven of non-perceiving beings,
and in the two mindless meditative absorptions, sleep, and fainting.

Having extensively distinguished the characteristics of the three transforming [natures] as the support for the two parts that transform, how should one understand that the provisional designation of self and dharmas based on consciousness transformation does not exist separately as real things, and that therefore everything is only consciousness?

If there is only consciousness, why did the World-Honored One say in various sutras that there are three natures?
One should know that the three natures are also not apart from consciousness. Why is this?

21. The other-dependent nature is born from discriminating conditions.
The perfectly accomplished nature is always far removed from the previous nature in it.
It is neither different nor not different,
Just like the nature of impermanence, etc., it is not seen in it.
If there are three natures, how is it that the World-Honored One says that all dharmas are without self-nature?
The verse says:
Establishing those three natures as without nature,
Therefore the Buddha secretly teaches that all dharmas are without nature.
The next one is without the nature of spontaneity,
Later, by being far removed from the previously grasped natures of self and dharmas,
It is also just suchness,
Always as its nature, therefore it is just the true nature of consciousness-only.
The following five verses clarify the stages of practice in consciousness-only. The treatise says:
In this way, who relies on how many stages to accomplish the nature and characteristics of consciousness-only?
How does one enter into realization?
It means possessing the two kinds of seed natures of the Great Vehicle:

First, the innate seed nature, which refers to the cause of the uncontaminated dharmas that one obtains by the power of dharmatÄ from beginningless time and is attached to the fundamental consciousness;
Second, the seed nature that is cultivated, which refers to what is accomplished by the perfuming of hearing the dharmas that flow out of the Dharma realm and so forth.
Only those who possess these two natures are able to realize and enter [the MahÄyÄna].
What are the five stages?
First, the stage of equipment, which refers to cultivating the MahÄyÄna aids to liberation. Relying on the nature and characteristics of consciousness, one is able to deeply believe and understand.
What are its characteristics?
A verse says:
Seeking to abide in the nature of consciousness-only,
One is still unable to subdue and eliminate the latent tendencies of the two graspings.

Second, the stage of added effort, which refers to cultivating the MahÄyÄna aids to penetration. In the stage of added effort, one is able to gradually subdue and eliminate the grasped and the grasper.
What are its characteristics?
It is said to be the nature of consciousness-only,
Because there is something attained, it is not truly abiding in consciousness only.
Third, the stage of penetrating understanding refers to the stage of the path of insight in which bodhisattvas abide. In the stage of penetrating understanding, one truly penetrates.
What are its characteristics?
The wisdom of the stage of penetrating understanding is completely without attainment.
At that time, one abides in consciousness only, because one is free from the characteristics of the two graspings.
Fourth, the stage of cultivation refers to the stage of the path of cultivation in which bodhisattvas abide. In the stage of cultivation, one truly sees reality and cultivates it repeatedly.
What are its characteristics?
The wisdom of the stage of cultivation is supramundane wisdom.
Because one abandons the two kinds of coarseness, one then realizes the transformation of the basis.
Fifth, the ultimate stage refers to abiding in unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, emerging from the obstructions and being perfectly illuminated, able to transform sentient beings in the future.
What are its characteristics?
The ultimate stage is inconceivable, good, and constant.
The body of liberation of bliss and ease is called the Dharma of the great sage.
